reviewText:
The minimalistic art style is good and so is the rhythmic timing, but that doesn't make up for the uninteresting controls or bland soundtrack.

Other minimalistic platformers (dust force, super meat boy, electronic super joy) can make up for their minimal graphics with slick, addictive controls. 140 just has move left/right at constant speed and jump. The wall grabs, double-jumps, running, sliding, etc that drive other similar games are lacking here.

Other rhythm games (bit trip runner, beat buddy) are able to make up for their limited controls with an addictive soundtrack. The thumping bass is great at first, but none of the levels have any sort of melodic hook and repetitive percussion can only get you so far.

Since most of the game objects are timed to match the music, you spend a lot of your play time waiting for the right time to jump... and waiting isn't fun.

Although the art style is great, it isn't quite enough to make it fun to play.

reviewText:
140 is a very short platformer game for the PC with a simple but distinctive aesthetic.

Story

The game has no story.

Gameplay

The gameplay is mostly fairly simple, but really has two modes; there is the gameplay during the levels, and the gameplay during the “bosses”.
The levels are all full of fairly standard platforming elements; moving platforms, “spikes/lava” which takes the form of static, and various other simplistic elements. The game does mix these up somewhat, with blocks which trigger other blocks to appear or disappear, expanding and contracting blocks which hover in place but can crush the player, blocks which temporarily turn themselves into ground which will kill the player if they touch it, and, in one level, brief, periodic periods of anti-gravity, where the player will fall up (but cannot jump off the ceiling).
The game is quite brief, consisting of only three levels of increasing difficulty, and checkpoints are frequent – a very necessary feature in the third, quite difficult level of the game. The player must periodically retrieve floating orbs and bring them to platforms to transform the level in order to continue on their way through it, and each time the level grows deadlier and more complicated, until they have reached the end of it.
At the end of every level there is a boss of sorts, though in reality they are merely segments of very different gameplay. The first one is a fairly traditional boss which shoots at the player from above and splits in half every time the player shoots it with a little hovering shooter which fires automatically every few seconds, requiring the player to time their presence underneath the boss to harm them. The second one has the player navigating through an environment which feels like they are racing down a narrowing track as an enemy whose touch means death zooms back and forth past the player. The third and final one has the player trying to defend themselves from enemies, pointing their blaster at them before they attack; as the player only has one shot per group of enemies, they have to make it count. This last one is quite frustrating as it plays heavily with interface screw, first by making it so that the blaster rotates either 90 or 180 degrees before firing (in a predictable pattern), and secondly, by shifting around the entire screen and thus giving the player only a very tiny amount of time to react. This was the most frustrating part of the game, and was a poor design choice as it felt very awkward rather than like a fun puzzle.

Graphics

The game has a very simple aesthetic to it; everything in the game is a geometric shape of some sort, and the player themselves turns from a triangle to a circle to a square depending on their movement and actions. Even the music is very simple, the game being silent at first, then gradually building up a more and more complicated soundtrack which beats in time with movements of objects in the environment.

Final Summary

The game is decent overall, but it is very short, and the third “boss” is quite obnoxious as the game experimented with interface screw in the place of interesting gameplay. On the whole the game was not terrible, but given its very short length, with the entire game likely taking no more than an hour to beat, and the frustrating final “boss”, there’s not a whole lot to recommend beyond its aesthetic.

reviewText: If you are even slightly bothered by bright and obnoxious colors, avoid this game. 140 is full of excessively contrasting and bright colors, to an extent which can only be sufficiently described as obnoxious
date:
and there is no way to dim the game in the options. The degree of col♥♥♥♥♥♥ varies by level, but most of my experience was wrought with eye strain. For a very short game like this, you don't want a headache to be your lasting impression on the player.

Beneath the pain is a fairly enjoyable precision platformer. The game doesn't have any real 'puzzles,' aside from figuring out where you need to go and not flunking the jump (which happens often), but the integration of the music is the real selling point. Hitting a checkpoint adds a new instrument to the soundtrack, and a new mechanic to the level tied to that instrument, and the mechanic is then used to progress.

It's a very compact experience, taking only an hour or two and sticking closely to its minimalist aesthetic. However, the levels really drag on; there are only three of them, and if the game runs you two hours, that's about 40 minutes per level. It's not too bad at first, since the checkpoints are quite frequent and there's hardly any delay to respawning and trying again. If the game ended after the third level, with no extra content, this would be an overall positive review; however, completing the main game unlocks a set of 'mirror levels,' and the game falls apart then.

Firstly, the mirror levels invert all the colors, leading to even more obnoxious color palettes than before. Then you replay the same levels, butmirrored - an interesting idea, except now death starts you over from the beginning. Of what might be a 20+ minute level. Which will end with some sort of bullet-hell boss. And good luck spacing your jumps if you're trying to defend your eyes from a painful assortment of hot pinks and sun yellows.

You need to learn these levels deeply, and practice them often, and dedicate lots of time to completing them. This is the core problem with this segment of the game: it is a 1-2 hour experience that then demands significantly more commitment in order to 'complete' it. You don't HAVE to finish the mirror levels, but if you uninstall it then, have you really completed" the game? Since you need to complete the mirror levels to unlock all the achievements
recommended: it suggests the devs don't think you've won until you've gone through that hell.\n\nIf you are content to play only half the game
hoursPlayed: you probably won't regret it. But overall
voteText: 140 does not respect the player's time
helpfulPercent: and as a result I won't recommend it."

reviewText:
This is a fantastic little indie gem, and here's why.

The game is just a simple platformer which is based around the music playing in the background. The music helps drive the player into moving and jumping at the right times, to over come obstacles. The music is quite smooth and soothing electronic tunes. Nothing too extreme.

In each of the levels, you're main objective is to go along and acquire a small floating ball, which starts to follow you after you've bumped into it. You then take it to a 'point' which then changes the music playing, and how the level looks / flows. New areas are accessible, static objects start to move and even the gravity can change.

The best part of this game, in my opinion, are the boss fights at the end of each level. Each one is well thought out, and brings a challenge to the player fighting them.

It's quite a short game, around 45 minutes to an hour, if you just want to play the base 3 levels.

You'll get a lot more time out of the game if you choose to do the 'advance' levels, which are mirror worlds of the first three, without any check points. So it's a die once, start the level again situation.

Well worth the full price, which isn't asking for much in my opinion.

In conclusion:
The levels are well planned out.
Fantastic music, fits into levels nicely.
Simple, but effective use of abstract colours.
Fantastic boss fights.
8 / 10, still playing.

reviewText:
I really am enjoying 140. Minimalist abstract art and design at its best. Every puzzle is unique and rewarding. As I played I became more and more aware of the music until I was relying on it to progress.
140 is a game with no filler. You must use everything you're given to solve the puzzles. But at the same time, this game is not your enemy trying to make you fail while you battle against it to win (like in most games e.g. your typical shooter or racing game), it is there to guide you through by teaching you as you go. When a new element is introduced in a puzzle game, so often I am just left to figure out myself what to do with it. In 140, you are subtly shown the mechanics of new elements before you must interact with them. This allows the player to always feel confident and in control. As the complexity and difficulty increased at just the right pace, I began to find some puzzles had a bit more too them than they seemed. I would have to watch as the elements reacted to the music and learn their patterns. Some of the puzzles may take you a minute or two to complete, but you are never confused for more than a few seconds. It’s the perfect mix of mental and physical skill.
If you’ve enjoyed games like Thomas Was Alone or The Impossible Game you will probably enjoy this.
140/10

reviewText:
To the untrained eye, the sheer minimalism and bold colours in 140 communicate an idea of simplicity and frugalism. A simple indie game for simple indie people.

This couldn't be further from the truth...

I've just spent an hour getting passed what I thought to be the last" level. Turns out
date: I'm only half way there. But my first playthrough was an enriching experience. The feedback loop the player recieves in the form of a changing soundtrack serves as an indicator of progression
recommended: and encourages you to keep going. This background mechanism combined with levels that layer on their complexity with each checkpoint the player completes
hoursPlayed: demonstrates a subtle mastery of game design and player psycology. 140 could have gone down the route of asking the player to hunt down the next check point

reviewText: This is an exceptionally mediocre game. There is an interesting premise, sort of, in the sense that a lot of the more complicated platforming is alleviated by timing your movements with the music. That's pretty cool but the developers never really expand upon this idea. The game is essentially a couple good ideas without an substance. To make matters worse, this game is incredibly easy (despite developer's claims) and very short. I beat the game in about 40 minutes with no inclination to play again.\n\nI would love to recommend this, I really would, but simply put it's a mediocre game with some great ideas that are never really executed beyond an extremely simplistic manner.  Will you like the game? Maybe. You will, however, be wishing there was more substance than what you are getting.

reviewText:
140-word review for 140:

Imagine a world of only two dimensions: length and height. Color that world with neon shades, sharp geometric landscapes and bind it together with minimalistic tech-house music. A world of stark beauty and remarkable simplicity; the player exists as a transforming piece of geometry - a square, triangle and circle altogether.

The geography of this flatland is not inert though. Environments comes to life in synergy with the music - music that is dependent on the player's progress in each of the three vistas. Can't make that jump? Well, the backing-track is probably missing an instrument; escorting a mysterious, floating orb to a docking station will add it to the soundtrack. Obstacles that were previously laying stubbornly static will come to life, rhythmically shifting all the way.

Glide, jump, roll, and shoot - 140 is an auditory and visual delicacy.

reviewText: I've never really questioned buying a game less than five dollars until now, and the more I think about it, the less this game justifies itself. Don't get me wrong, this game provides an interesting and unique experiance; however, that experiance is not increadably unique, nor does it last more than an hour or so. There exist other rythem-based platformers on steam, many of which are worth the money you spend on them. If you already want to buy this game, you'll probably enjoy it. Hell, if you know nothing about this game you'll probably enjoy it, but at the end of the day you'll be stuck with 3 (or 5, after the sale) bucks out of your pocket and a completed game that has no replayability. There are many other games you can buy for the same amount that will exceed this game on those terms. In conclusion, unless you have a super strong urge to buy this game, 140 is worth your time, but not your money.

reviewText: 140 is a 2d platformer that mixes challenging gameplay with amazing music but will you want to play 140 ? Theres no story in 140 but the game is amazing none the less. 140 consists of three stages and three reverse stages. The game also has a mirror stage that increases the difficulty and makes the game insanely difficult. Now for the bad. The game is incredibly short. Overall 140 is a fun and cheap game that i suggest you check out. 140 is a great platformer also has a great soundtrack. I give 140 a 8/10

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: Don't pay full price.

If I remember correctly, I paid 5 bucks for this game. It isn't worth that much, even if it is only 5 bucks. The game is fun, and very interestingly designed. I love the rhythmic levels and it was a joy playing through them.

But the game is just too short. I beat the 3 levels in something under 30 minutes, maybe? My play time since then has been the mirrored versions of those levels. The mirrored versions are literally exact mirrors of the levels you already played, so there isn't anything really new or exciting.

The only difference is that dying in the mirrored levels returns you to the main area and you have to restart the level all over. If anything, that leads to a pain in the ♥♥♥ more than fun replay value.

So, initially, the game is enjoyable. And I would recommend you try it out. But get it for as cheap as possible. Spending 5 bucks on something I beat in 30 minutes and haven't really enjoyed since left a sour taste in my mouth.

Again, the time I played was enjoyable and intriguing. I just wish that there was more to it all.

reviewText:
This game is decent, when you have the patience for it...

...that being said, it's rare that you'll ever have the patience.

Since it's a game based on rhythm and patterns, you probably won't be surprised to hear that it gets very tedious and boring, very fast. And when you do get bored, or rage quit, because you've played one section 20 times over, because that millisecond screws you over, guess what? You'll have to play the whole level over again to get back to that point! If you need to take a break, you have to alt-tab, and come back later, or else you'll lose all your progress on that level.

This is especially annoying because the bosses are stupidly enraging, so if you get bored or rage quit, have fun playing that whole level to get back!

Really, all this game needs to be a great game is in-level saving, not just overworld saving.

reviewText:
Pros:

+The games logo looks cool
+Excellent sound design, kind of a cross between a Rhythem Game, and Platformer
+The games visuals are quite appealing despite looking like it was made in MSpaint

Cons:

-Not that fun
-the reward for the games difficulty is only a slight change in the soundtrack, not nearly enough to keep you going
-The game does not save your progress so if you quit the game you lose your progress

Overall:
This game is very bizzare, and although it has some interesting design features, like sound cues for when you need to time your jumps, it just isn't enough to keep you coming back Also the lack of a savegame feature also hurts it severely as well. This is a unique title with a lot of potential sadly squandered by poor execution. The final boss's pattern is so poorly designed as well that you can't even beat it via studying it's movements, as they are so erratic... This game tries to be Dark Souls but fails.

reviewText:
I almost never take the time to write a review of a steam game, most steam games I'm simply pleased with but not blown away, occasionally I'll write a positive review of a steam game I absolutely love. However, I don't believe I've taken the time to write a negative review of any steam game before this, so take all that into consideration when reading this review.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

Forgive the caps lock but I had to be clear, this game is a very good example of what people mean when they call a game indie" as a pejorative. Is it lazy? Yep. Is it self congradulatory? Yep. Is it overpriced and exploitative in design such that it takes a lot of time to beat just because of bad game design choices? Yep.

Think what you will about "miminalism" but time and time again the indie community has shown that they believe it to mean "getting away with being lazy by calling it an artistic choice". This game uses solid colors like crazy
recommended: they are just solid colors. In every area of game design aside from the music (which is decent) this game cuts corners on production.\n\nFirst of all the mechanics consist of little more than basic "avoid hazards
hoursPlayed: time jumps". The hazards are a lazy static design. Honestly
voteText: this game looks a whole lot like what a game would look like if you set out with the idea of "making the game requiring the least amount of effort to make and charging the most money you could get away with". And you might suggest this is cynical or baseless
helpfulPercent: but think of this: This game does not have an options screen. You can adjust window size before playing but once you are in
votesHelpful: you are in. Why doesn't this game have an options screen? Pretty much every game in the past 20 years has had an options screen
votesTotal: but for some reason this game is "above having an options screen".\n\nWhat nerve the developer must have to think so highly of this game. And now
votesFunny: for the coding
commentsCount: this game could be coded by most decent coders in a week or two. That's it! Compare that to a game like "The Binding of Isaac" a game with so much more depth and variety that most programmers couldn't even code or imagine. And take note
column16: both games cost the same amount. That's the biggest insult is the price point. This game has THREE LEVELS. That's it
column17: and how does the developer pad out the game with "additional content"? He adds THE SAME THREE LEVELS again but with the X axis inverted on the level.\n\n"Mirror mode" is acknowledged as incredibly easy to do
column18: it's one line of code most of the time
column19: inverting a level can be done in under a minute
column21: that's why some games have it as a "cheat code". Here
column22: the almighty genius of a developer thinks so much of his game that he thinks these 3 inverted levels without checkpoints constitute "new levels".\n\nWhat really irks me though is that somehow some people seem to be buying into this game. Read the reviews

reviewText:
Let me say that I completed the game and tried giving it a fair chance.

tl:dr Don't buy, the game is frustrating, has bad music, and is only 50 minutes long at most.

This game is extremely frustrating and miserable. The music is just straight up bad, and minimalism is used as an excuse for glitchy lo-fi tunes. In a good music based platformer you should feel like everything is moving naturally, and you should be moving in time with the beat. This game has you pausing to wait for a platform to reset constantly. And if you're a nanosecond off you will die.

The game also has 3 boss fights, each one more frustrating than the last. 1 is a bullet hell shoot, except you can only move slowly and jump, 2 is dodging an enemy that moves about .3 seconds before the beat, and the last one is like a rhythm game where you shoot in four directions...except that your aim moves away from where you are shooting ON PURPOSE, in addition to your targets moving at total random.

reviewText:
A great rhythmic platformer. You can cover the three levels in an hour, after which you can attempt to do them in mirror mode w/o checkpoints. This is the real test because when playing the levels for the first time, you can die as many times and therefore the importance of keeping the beat/rhythm may be lost on you. But when you play the levels in mirror mode, where every death sends you to the START of each level...you will learn how important keeping the beat is.

It is fairly priced for what it's worth. Challenging, but tight controls. Good music, but the graphics, quite honestly, are just simple (nothing great but nothing bad as well).

Recommended for precision platform lovers, or rhythm game aficionados.

An interesting rythm game that looks and plays very well, bringing puzzles and platforming into an interesting world that changes with the music around you.  It is though, a game without a return point once you close it out and one that is also rage-indusingly difficult at times.  Eventually decided to put it down and walk away after my 30th attempt at the final boss.

Sure, game, I'll gladly give you half an hour of my time, if that's what'll take to play through the level and reach the boss.\nWhat's that?? You won't save my progress unless I beat the really frustrating boss, that took me about 30 minutes just to reach it and if I quit now I'll have to go through the entire level again???\nOh, ok let me bend over.

The game has a nice soundtrack, that interacts with the world. I like that the changes don't necessarily happen on the main beats, but that it is quite polyrhythmic. Although I would have liked to hear more variety. On the second playthrough it could become repetitive. Maybe add an alternating lead voice.\nThe boss fights were interesting and inovated well on their mechanics, although the first playthrough wasn't that hard for me. Finished it in a 1h lunch break.\nI'm looking forward to the second playthrough without checkpoints.

One of the best experiences I've ever made gaming.
Yes, you can walk through the whole game in under one hour, but the trip is amazing.
I really love the minimalistic geometric design and the waving colors everywhere.
But the best thing about the game is the really fantastic music and sound design.
Everything you do results in a sound that plays well to the background music.

Enjoy this game the best at night with a nice Stereo, or realy good headphones,
turn out the light and forget about anything else, playing one hour with a really big
smile on your face.

reviewText: 140 is one of the most enjoyable platformer games I have ever played; I just wish it were longer. This game is great because not only is they're really fun music but the game pretty much requires you get into the music in order to progress. It just goes to show that no level of graphics or storyline is needed to make a good and challenging game, as it uses basic geometric shapes to create an enjoyable (yet disappointingly short) game.\n\nThe only problem with this game is how short it is, I would love to see a more levels be released for 140 or perhaps a sequel as this incredibly short game leaves you wanting so much more.

Fairly short rhythm platform game.  It took me a bit to figure out what was going on, given that I initially saw a solid black screen with a single white square in the center that I could change into a triangle or circle with no obvious effect.  Once the game got going, however, I finished what appeared to be the whole thing in two sittings.

The music is fun, and nearly central to the game play.  (I haven't tried playing with the music off; watching the background might suffice, but I wouldn't recommend it.)  Graphics are minimal, but represent the world well, once you understand what they mean.  (How long before the world forgets what static looked like, though?)  Puzzles are occasionally challenging, with one lengthy battle (for lack of a better word) at the end of each level.

I'm not sure I can justify paying full price, but on sale it's a nice little piece.

Art style is both pretty and pretty basic, gameplay is very simple and the difficulty is not too bad. Would buy for $0.33 and 1/3rd of a cent

Wow intense game. Simple concept pulled off really nicely. Musically timed platforming is not very common. At times I was better off without the music but for the most part it worked well. I haven't been so engrossed in a simple platformer like that in a while. I thoroughly enjoyed it. Definitely recommended for an afternoon of platforming if that's what you are into.

Totally worth the price for the experience. This is a game about design through and through. It's almost unique to have a minimalistic game that is built with such care. I would also say the game has replayability if you enjoy the music by doing it backwards. Just sit back, enjoy and marvel in this design gem.

I'd give this game a conditional recommendation.  As others have mentioned, it has a certain novelty to it, with the combination of rhythm game and plaformer mechanics.  The difficulty between level progression and boss fights can be rather severe, particularly on level 3, but it isn't insurmountable by any means.  That said, the game is very short and light on content.  If you can pick it up during a sale or bundle for a buck or two, you might want to pull the trigger, but there probably isn't enough here for most gamers to feel that they got their money's worth at full price.

Here's the thing - just like everyone else is saying, 140 is very short. It took me exactly an hour to complete. If you ever see this game on sale, you might as well get it. But I'm not convinced I would spend over 8 cents a minute to play this again.

I like rhythm games a lot, and the idea of a rhythm platformer is very attractive to me. One major con of 140 is that, although the trailer tells a different tale, there is minimal emphasis on rhythm. Though it seems odd to say that about a rhythm game, it's true; the designers spent more time on style, and not enough on functionality and creativity. The second boss, for instance, not only had no rhythm, it was easier without the music. This should never be true for any rhythm game: there should be an emphasis on rhythm.

Gameplay is fun at times, tedious at others. It's quite easy, most of the time. To be honest, it's quite forgettable. The third boss is amazing, and the first one isn't that bad, but anything in between failed to excite me.

The appearance of the game, holistically, is nice! I really like the minimalist feel. The controls, as well, were simple and nice.

The designer probably considers the three secret achievements, which can be gotten by going through a mirror-mode version of the levels without dying ever, as replay value". I have absolutely no incentive to play it this way

★★★☆☆ (3/5 - Ok)

(WARNING: This review contains mild spoilers)

140 is a minimalistic puzzle-platforming game featuring unique, rhythm-based obstacles and a vast array of vibrant colours. 140 explores interesting concepts by combining platforming and rhythm features. Generally these features come in the form of timed jumps and moving to specific beats given by the background tracks.

I personally found these concepts unique and enjoyable but what let the game down for me was its lack of content. There are only three 10-20 minute levels (six, if you include the inverted levels) and there is a disturbing lack of instructions or information about anything going on when you begin the game (to be fair though the goal is easy to pick up once you get started).

In terms of story, well... there is none... but the gameplay and audio are the two aspects in which this game shines. You can tell that the musician that produced the upbeat soundtracks and catchy sound effects spent a lot of time perfecting it for the game.

The controls are quite smooth and handle well, this makes the difficult parts of levels somewhat more tolerable (especially the bosses).

In terms of replay value, you have the opportunity to play the three original levels again without checkpoints for a real challenge but apart from that there isn't really anything else to do in the game.

I would suggest getting this game if you feel like something different from your average platform game and have a decent hour or two to spare but apart from that I would give it a miss. I feel bad about rating this game negatively but I felt it didn't live up to the expectations I got from reading about the game before I installed it.

reviewText: Great and simply game! Absolute gameplay and atmosphere! Many Large videogames studios should learn from this game how to accomplished FUN!

2 hours of exhilarating & pulsating fun is how this rhythm game can and should be described. People have different tastes, of course, but for lovers of puzzles and those who don't mind a bit--only a bit because this game isn't THAT difficult--of mental workout, 140 is a winner. Screens are simple, colorful--you might even wanna snap a couple of them and use them as wallpapers on your HD LCDs (I did)--and reverberate with pulsating beat music. Game's beat music is the key to way forward, because you will need to time your moves in rhythm with these beats. Puzzles are intelligently crafted and made me laugh in amazement when  I figured them out. There are, in total, three levels, and at the end of each level, you are challenged with a boss screen. The third level, however, has two boss screens, the last one of which is a disappointment since it is solvable with a fixed sequence of key presses however many times you play it. I like this game in particular above many other puzzlers as it doesn't test you on how fast you are at your keyboard, but instead challenges your patience and alertness by offering you unlimited time for each puzzle piece. 9/10.

reviewText: 7/10 - I hesitated getting this and waited for a sale.... Once I played I realized it would have been well worth the full price.
I am the colour spectrum overlord.

140 is an indie minimalistic 2D platformer based on music. It starts out simple, but becomes very challenging as the levels progress. You play as simple shapes which change as your movements differ (i.e. run = circle, jump = triangle, stop = square). Essentially, you have to use the music as your guide to the end, as it changes with each stage, which creates more complex beats for the obstacles you are faced with to follow.

All-in-all, I'd say this game is very impressive. I was surprised that I enjoyed playing it so much, and actually wanted more after I had beat it. For something so simple and minimal, I never thought that I'd be so in love with it. I spent $5, and I don't regret a penny of that price, regardless of the length of the game.

TL;DR:

Pros:
-Simple
-Challenging
-Good progression of complexity
-Great soundtrack

Cons:
-Too short, not enough levels (~40 minutes playtime)

Scores:
Gameplay: 8/10
Soundtrack: 10/10
Style: 10/10
Graphics: 9/10
Addictiveness: 10/10
Overall: 9/10

140 is a game with slick visuals and great electronic music. Be warned that some people will not find this art style appealing. Gameplay wise this game is fairly easy. Once you are familiar with its pattern, you can go through the obstacle course and complete the game. This also means that this game is fair for either a platformer or a rhythm game, no matter which angle you look at it. 140 is such a small game that people absolutely terrible at platformers or rhythm games (or both) can complete it within a few hours, let alone veterans, so I wouldn't recommend purchasing it at full price. For a discounted price, grab it for your audiovisual enjoyment.

I only played the first three levels because 140 is not interesting enough to merit the difficulty increase.
I got this game in an artsy" Humble Bundle but I didn't know anything about it until I played.  I would describe 140 as a rythym platformer.  You are a shape (which changes between circle
date: square and triangle) and you have to navigate the world and platforms to get these little balls and put them in these pits.  It sounds simple but the cool part is the techno music playing on each level.  The platforms and obstacles in each level move to the different beats in the music.  It's tough but it's all just really pretty and cool.  I definitely recommend it."

reviewText: A complete masterpiece, 140 questions modern gaming techniques, and is one of the more satisfying games you'll play this year. The entire game took me 45 minutes to complete, but I rarely got frustrated at bits, and just by closing my eyes and listening to the music, I was back on track to completion. This game takes us way back to the borderline arcade era, toying only with the level of difficulty throughout the different levels, but keeps it interesting by introducing a new way to interact with the world at each stage of completion.\nTurn up your sound, put your fingers on the arrow keys, and get ready to go through a completely psychedelic experience, without ever leaving your seat.

This is a game that has to be played in order to understand why it is so good.\n\nYou're given three controls here: left, right, and jump, but it's the way the game effortlessly teaches you how to navigate through its relatively obscure mechanics along with its enjoyable music and fantastic art design is what makes it so unique.  Even though it's a short experience, it's so well designed and immersive that it really doesn't matter.  This game is a shining example of show not tell" design

reviewText: Great game to experience a seizure

Wow, I definitely did not expect this game to be that good.  I just played through the three levels (spoiler: you're able to play through 3 more that are mirrored versions of the regular ones after beating the first three), and I really enjoyed this.  The visuals, gameplay, and music are simple yet beautiful, and the levels and boss battles are all really creative and quite different from anything else I've played.  This is one of the better games I've played in a long time.\n\nAmazing game, just a bit too short (I was fine with the length of this game since I got it in a Humble Bundle, but for others looking for this game: expect a solid hour or so of gameplay to get through the main game, and then probably a few more hours for the mirrored levels).

A neat little platformer. Will take about an hour to beat. This is good because there is NO menu and NO way to save any progress.  Still, very fun and brief experimental little game. Worth a few bucks and an hour.

Really was surprised by this game, it's short but really well crafted. Honestly the closest I think I've ever played to a true rhythm platformer and that's what makes it so strong; the rhythm elements are well-implemented and the level designs use them effectively without ever unfairly. The game's honestly not too difficult to clear normally, though the reverse stages certainly present a bit more of a challenge. The bosses also tend to break the mold of the game, though they're not too challenging once you figure out strategies for them. The minimal graphic style I'm neutral on; doesn't detract from the game but doesn't add to it either, it's just there and I'm fine with that.\n\nOverall though, a neat little game that I'm glad I played.

So I got 140 because I got a discount from making a badge, and after playing half way through the game I can honestly state that rhythm is everything with this game. An offset of beat or timing will cause you to have to start back at your last spawn point, and after the first part of the game you can try to do the levels flawless and reverse.

140 has good game design when it comes to learning how to play the game, and they ease you into it. There tutorial level where it teaches you how to jump and what does what, you just kind of get a vibe of what you need to do, and every time one completes a section of the level, they throw a new element at the player but show them in a nearly safe environment,  (you could still fail), how to the new element functions.

The game is simple and is easy to understand. However I have found that this game can hurt the eyes based on their color schemes and there are parts where I would fear for those whom have epilepsy.

So if you are one with such problems I suggest you Don't play this game, however if you are not a person with such problems, then by all means. Its a cheap fun game.

An interesting experience, it's quite amazing to play a platformer in such a way that you synchronise your actions to the music.\nBasically the game is affected by music, or the music is affected by the game. You generally use the rythm to determine what actions the environment will make and the boss fights are particularly interesting. No two are alike and it was cool to see what they came up with. Maybe abit short for the current price (5-ish bucks) but well worth checking out.
Very fluid with audio and all, great for a simple platformer.
I finished this game in about 60 minutes. It had a few good challenges.

WOW.

OH MY GOD.

140 is short, but other than that it is almost what I would call the 'perfect game'.

The gameplay is challenging and, at times, even diabolical - but never insurmountable.
The visuals are an abstract beauty - doing more with shapes than most games do with realistic environments.
The soundtrack is one of the best I've ever heard - so good, I'm even going to get it for my iPod at some point (if I can find it - it's probably somewhere on bandcamp).

It is amazing and jaw-dropping. Play it, and be wowed.

9.9 / 10

(One thing, though - 140 IS a near-perfect game, but considering its length it isn't quite worth the $5 needed to play it. I would suggest snapping it up either as soon as it goes on sale or as soon as you have a coupon or something for it.)

Basically, this game is a platformer. But what makes this game different from other, is the fact that everything in the stage acts to the rythm of the background music. And everytime you enter the next stage, you get another 'beat'.
This game is fun, addictive, and challenging! The music is really good.
It has a well thought-out, innovative gameplay.
It may be short for some, but it was worth it. I enjoyed the experience I had.
You'll love this game if you like other rythm games/basic platformers.

There seems to be a trend for experience based games cropping up over time, like Dyad or in this case 140.  In all cases, the price is a little high - not because the game is not worth that much, but because experience-based games tend to be overshadowed by sweeping soundtracks and beautifully rendered RPG games, or FPSes which have been with us as a gaming community since the early days alongside RTSes.

I might not have bought this for five dollars - heck, I didn't even know this game existed.  However, the Weekly Humble Bundle this week was an excellent time to learn it existed and to plop it into my library.  I might be biased - I produce music of all sorts for fun, and I've always had my eye on music-based games.  I also know when to say no to a game, and this was not that time.

140 is not a normal music-based game.  At least, when Normal for music-based games is Audiosurf or Beat Hazard or DDR.  140 turns everything upside down to create a very simplified gaming experience that lends itself to actually experiencing the game.  In the end, a short set of gameplay sessions is what this game is meant to provide, as are most game-like experiences, though I do wish there were more levels.

So after all that, is it worth five bucks?  Ask yourself this - are you looking for a normal game, or a game-like experience?

For 5 bucks, definitely worth buying!

reviewText: A fantastic ,simplistic and challenging yet way too short platformer. This is the kind of game you really learn to love for what it is. The kind of game that makes you pray that the developer surprises you again with such a magnificent gem.

You may probably think that the name of the game has nothing to do with the actual game. But truthfully, it means that you are able to shapeshift into 3 different kinds of shapes: Square, Triangle, and Circle.

Yeah I dont f***ing know.

THE REVIEW-

Everything this game has to offer is given through powerful musical tunes in the background. All of the enemies (obstacles) are presented with unique consquences to bypass. If you fail, you may get mad. If you fail more than once after failing prior to the second time, you will be prone to ragequitting.

The beats are solid and energetic, as well as the entirety of the game. One thing that may ♥♥♥♥ off many players who dare challenge their minds to this near-impossible work of art, is the frequent need to have a long walk from your last checkpoint. While in mid-game, checkpoints become more subtle and unreasonably missing- as to add more difficulty to the hand-sweating completionists' necessity to quit.

Remember, even if a game like this pisses you off most of your journey into it-
just remind yourself of those hand-sweating completionits who have to go through the whole game spending 5+ hours on it, regardless of its length/duration.

***8/10***

-Hand-Sweating Completionist
This minimalistic indie has some sick puzzle beats. Not too short of a game, and being a perfectionist is worth a shot.

First time I've reviewed a game on Steam.

Loved it. There are a precious few games that can make me smile and laugh while I die.

Spin the Black Circle did this best... it's a flash game that I would pay anything for a PC port.

Another one that comes to mind is Bit Trip Runner. It was amazing... ridiculously difficult.

And now I'll add 140 to the list. Way too short. There are flaws in the level design, the music as great as it is can become repetive, and it's still on of the best games I've ever played.

My wish would be 30 more levels, and more music from the same composer.

Would I reccomend it? Absolutely. At $5 it's a must-buy.
Great music, great platforming, great game.

My only gripe would be that, as a music rhythm-based game, it sometimes punishes your haste as it requires sharp timing of your movement (but nowhere near as frustrating as, say, N+" videogame does) and you just don't want to stop the flow.

This game is a game that I really enjoy, but that may only be because I love simplistic/pixel rhythm games.

Graphics:

7/10

The graphics are great because they are nice and simple, and go along with the beat of the music. They didn't score higher because I feel they could've looked a bit nicer, but still stayed pretty simplistic.

Sound:

8/10

There aren't really many sound effects, but that's okay because one of the main parts of the game is the music. Although, since the music is important to solving the different puzzles, it loops over and over, and after a while can get a bit annoying if there is a puzzle you're having trouble with.

Story:

N/A

While there are different levels broekn up logically, there isn't really a rhyme or reason to what you're doing and why.

Length:

4/10

There are only 3 levels in the game, however, they are decently long, It is acceptable because everything else about the game is great.

Overall:

7/10

I definately recommend this game for people who like a cool experience for a small price.

Very fun game, it is an interesting concept that we shall ponder for a moment. You control a square that turns into a circle when moving that turns into a traingle when jumping. Much like being bored in geometry class, you move these shapes around in what can be considered a doodle of a world. There is music playing that, spoiler-alert, tries to hypnotize you in order to make you move your triangle-square-circle hybrid to the beat. As you run, gun and jump through this elaborate world, you start encountering evil staic whose only goal is, much like in a real-life geometry class, to make you pay attention and stop doodling. There is also a hardcore mode where failing once makes you restart the game from the beggining instead of at the checkpoints as usual. I find this mode to be a bit insulting as in real life you do not get second chance, so it is in my humble opinion that in hardcore mode if you die once the game should auto uninstall and you should get a steam badge saying you are a failure, once again to keep up with how it is in real life. Overall, this game managed to rustle my jimmies on more than one occasion, however I proud to give this game a 32/37!
The bad thing of this game, is how short it is.

Fairly short rhythm platform game.  It took me a bit to figure out what was going on, given that I initially saw a solid black screen with a single white square in the center that I could change into a triangle or circle with no obvious effect.  Once the game got going, however, I finished what appeared to be the whole thing in two sittings.

The music is fun, and nearly central to the game play.  (I haven't tried playing with the music off; watching the background might suffice, but I wouldn't recommend it.)  Graphics are minimal, but represent the world well, once you understand what they mean.  (How long before the world forgets what static looked like, though?)  Puzzles are occasionally challenging, with one lengthy battle (for lack of a better word) at the end of each level.

I'm not sure I can justify paying full price, but on sale it's a nice little piece.

I only completed the three 'normal' levels.., but I can safely say that this game is worth 5$ whether you beat the bonus levels or not, hands down. It's short and sweet for someone who's familiar with rhythm, and an enticing challenge for those who aren't. I fall into the latter group. I've never been musically inclined myself, but the concept is spectacular and beautifully executed. The background is comprised of sound bars that aren't just for show; they really do reflect the behavior of the music, which is an integral part of the game.

The main objective as a platformer is to retrieve orbs that, for solidarity, I'll call beat orbs. These orbs can be deposited in various parts of the map in subwoofer-esque circles in the floor to add a new beat to the music and influence the behavior of the map. Indeed, there are far too few visual ques(The fact that it's minimalistic is just a bonus) for you to be able to succeed without training your ears to the music. Every little action produces a sound just like in real life, and bringing yourself in tune with these intermingling sounds and focusing on individual sounds are the key to success. I won't say similar things haven't been done before (See: Devil's Tuning Fork[www.devilstuningfork.com]), but never have they been done quite like this.

Normally I'm very critical of anything with less than three dimensions, call it a character flaw if you must... but this game does something that simply can't be done in 3d and for that I applaud this game.


I also recorded my experiences with the game if you'd like to see what you're getting for your money.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=79avp3FqxxY
Simple, perfect, mesmerising, incredible.

140 is a captivating platformer indie game. You play as a shape which changes forms based on what action you're doing. If
you're running, you'll be a circle, if you're jumping you'll be a triangle, and if you're idle you'll be a triangle. This game's visuals
and sounds are a major part of the game's mechanics, which is interesting and relatively original.

The game begins quiet and very simple, but as the game progresses it throws more and more mechanics at you, until you reach a point where the game is extremely tense and a bundle of fun at the same time.
Throughout the short campaign you will experinece 3 chapters, each with a unique boss at the end. At this point the game becomes less of a platformer and more of a bullethell game, as you crazily dive from side to side trying to dodge the mass of  bullets flaling across the screen.
The major fault with this game is that the campaign is far too short, barely lasting an hour. Which leaves you just getting started with the game by the time you're asked to pack up and leave. Which is a shame as the game has alot going for it.
and considering the ramp up time of this game you barely get any time to enjoy the game at all.

In conculsion this game is enjoyable, ignoring the somewhat cumbersome beginning the game is fast pased and envigorating. But the major downfall of this game is that the campaign is far too short to justify spending much more than 1-2 GBP.

reviewText: Short but sweet, reminds me of FRACT OSC. Hypnotic, Synesthetic and Psychedelic.\nBeware though, there's only three levels. Really was surprised by this game, it's short but really well crafted. Honestly the closest I think I've ever played to a true rhythm platformer and that's what makes it so strong; the rhythm elements are well-implemented and the level designs use them effectively without ever unfairly. The game's honestly not too difficult to clear normally, though the reverse stages certainly present a bit more of a challenge. The bosses also tend to break the mold of the game, though they're not too challenging once you figure out strategies for them. The minimal graphic style I'm neutral on; doesn't detract from the game but doesn't add to it either, it's just there and I'm fine with that.\n\nOverall though, a neat little game that I'm glad I played.

So I got 140 because I got a discount from making a badge, and after playing half way through the game I can honestly state that rhythm is everything with this game. An offset of beat or timing will cause you to have to start back at your last spawn point, and after the first part of the game you can try to do the levels flawless and reverse.

140 has good game design when it comes to learning how to play the game, and they ease you into it. There tutorial level where it teaches you how to jump and what does what, you just kind of get a vibe of what you need to do, and every time one completes a section of the level, they throw a new element at the player but show them in a nearly safe environment,  (you could still fail), how to the new element functions.

The game is simple and is easy to understand. However I have found that this game can hurt the eyes based on their color schemes and there are parts where I would fear for those whom have epilepsy.

So if you are one with such problems I suggest you Don't play this game, however if you are not a person with such problems, then by all means. Its a cheap fun game.

To wrap up, this game has a lot of potential, being a simple game which can bring you delight while you play it. Maybe for a sale or on a bundle, otherwise, stay away from this game, just 5 dollars you could've spent on something that would hold your time for longer.

reviewText:
140 status: Completed primary campaign yet to 100%

Oh I am so damn conflicted about this review! I really don't know which way to go with it.

Look, this is a flash game. It has gorgeous visuals and sounds but it is still a flash game. This is okay though. I am absolutely a million times behind small time indie developers getting a more minimalist yet heavily polished experience onto steam so they can make some money and start off, even if the whole experience feels like a flash game. An example of this done right is Antichamber. It has the most blindingly shiny polish ever and it has length to boot. 140 has....well it has the polish at least.

140 is a moderately challenging platform game. Sadly though it only has 3 very short levels and it can be completed within a lunch break. Now you may be thinking that this might be a Nintendo hard game that makes up for its short life span with complicated levels, and really the levels aren't that hard at all, in fact the game doesn't really start to show its teeth until the third and final boss fight, and that's only because I'm completely thick and it took me a while to get used to the switch of gravity. I expect with practice you could probably speed run this without glitching in 25 or so minutes.

That is not to say that this is bad, by no means at all is it bad. Were it a free flash game it would be up there in most peoples top 10s. My only real complaints is the hit box seems to be a little bit out.

You see this is a platformer with static areas that will kill you and push you back to the last check point. There are no enemies to speak of which makes the experience feel a little lonely, rather the environment reacts with the music in the background which means that you have to get into rhythm with the sound track in order to progress which makes a very nice experience. The graphics are very simple and programmer arty which is fine with me. I see this as a very clever way of doing your first steps if you know a little about code but don't have the resources to hire a team. However everything is incredibly blocky but its stylistic, I am kind of on the fence for graphics. The hit detection seems a little unfairly sided to the static too, resting against a wall that suddenly changes will kill you, its only a pixel but you should really give the player the benefit of the doubt in most cases.

When you finish the game you can play a hard mode version of it, sadly though all the stages just go from right to left instead and they removed the check points. Not really worth much but at least its there, might add another hour or 2 to the game if you want to get your moneys worth. I would also like to point out that this game runs fine on low graphics for me but was a bit slow on high with my native res. I personally could not tell the difference and as its just 2d squares coloured I don't really see how you could up or lower the graphics, my rigs a little old now but it might be something for you to look out for.

At time of writing the game is £4 on steam and when I give my rating and recommendation I have to take that into account. Now remember I like the fact that these smaller flash type games are getting on steam, they are good fun little games, but they need a little bit more than what this offers and in this case its length. As I say, were this a freebie on newgrounds it would probably be getting an 8 or a 9 but as it stands I can only really give it a 4.
Don't take that as it being crap though! This score is just relative to its price. Make sure that you do play it if its in a bundle and you own it. But unless you really really really love the music/minimalistic genre you might want to wait until its a steam sale for at least half price or you might feel disappointed.

Remember 4/10 just means its below average, it doesn't mean you can't have fun with it. You may feel differently and I would love to hear your reasonings. Feel free to comment :)

It is a very visual game with some clever levels that use the beat of the audio to time changes. You will have to listen to different sounds for different objects and time your jumps accordingly. Some sections can be frustrating but overall the game is pretty easy once you get the hang of it. Now the game does not take very long to finish but I love going back to it whenever I have half an hour to relax and play a game that just makes me smile. No stress, no frustrations, just simple gameplay and good music.

Pros

- Music
- Design
- Clever gameplay
- Checkpoints in the right places

Cons

- I wish there were more levels, more bosses. I would be happy to pay around $5-$10 for an expansion or something!

Definitely worth it, always nice to get it when there is a sale though, I have seen it as low as $1.

I'm a big fan of rhythm games, but this one does need to be recognized as a niche target audience.

The fairly steady technopunk(i'm not sure of the exact musical flavor) rhythm and enough checkpoints keep the game from being overly challenging. Instead of rushing through (which will certainly result in several deaths), most sections of all the levels almost REQUIRE you to pause and wait for the path to become clear. In some ways this is enjoyable, as it emphasizes the mental reasoning over twitch reflexes, but it can also come across like driving down a highway and hitting every light red; even if there is absolutely no rush, it gets frustrating.

Everything in the game is responsive to different track sections that the player activates to progress through the game, but the caveat to this is that while the level is perfectly in time with the music, this actually requires the character to move OUT of sync with that same music. Instead of jamming to the beat, you're really jamming in counterpoint, almost like you are actually fighting against the track. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but for those who have grown up on or mastered DDR, Guitar Hero, Elite Beat Agents, or even games like Audiosurf or the Bit Trip series, will find themselves getting a number of annoying flase starts when they try to move to the music and match it's timing.

The controls are smooth, and incredibly simple. This could easily translate to a smartphone, using the gyroscope for movement and a single button press to jump, or the bottom half of the screen split for left and right movement, with the entire top half of the screen as a big jump button that the thumb for the inactive direction can press.

It only has 3 levels, which are then recycled into mirror levels that strip out all the checkpoints for extra challenge. There are Boss battles" and I really enjoyed the first and second battles for these

reviewText:
140 is very short and very simple, maintaining a cool, music-based mechanic throughout the entire experience. It is not a particiularly difficult game, but provides enough challenge to keep one interested.

The only negative I really have for the game is my personal experience with the final segment. I understood exactly what the mechanics at play were and how they followed the music, but visually it just really messed with me in a way that I could not wrap my brain around quickly enough. I essentially beat it through luck and have no desire to ever go back to the game because of that. Still, I think it is unfair to dismiss the game because of one short segment that likely will not be as bad for most people.

140 is worth a play, for sure. It might not be the most impressive title around, but it succeeds on every front that it sets out to, and that is far more than most games can claim.
Great short game but very interesting. The combination of visuals and sound aims for a great experience.

8/10 would recommend, but buy on sale.

140 is a side scrolling game where the objective is to complete levels while avoiding and/or jumping over obstacles.
The game itself is not actually very long. I bought it a long time ago on humble when it was on sale. It took me like an hour and half to complete. It has primarily 3 levels. To complete each level, you have to pass a series of smaller obstacle avoiding courses and capture a ball-thingy and take it back to the capture point (think of it like Capture the Flag mode, where you have to capture and take the flag to a capture point, except in this case, the flag is a ball).  The game primarily relies on following rhythm to jump and/or avoid obstacles. The soundtrack is pretty awesome, I wish I could get it outside the game. All the puzzles have rhythm which once you get a hang of is a breeze to complete. Fortunately, the game does not end there. With in each level, the rhythm and obstacles change often enought to give you some challenge.
In all there are actually 6 levels, (3 main, 3 repeated excepted tougher levels). The difference is that the three main levels have checkpoints spanned over levels to give you a chance to resume if you screwed up. The 3 repeated levels do not have checkpoints so you have to finish them without making a mistake or you will have to start over. As I said, the 3 main levels took me like an hour and a half tops, so its a very short game in that sense.
Also warning, this game has colours flashing like crazy so if you are prone to having seizures or headaches, I would recommend avoiding this game. I had occasions where my head would suddenly hurt from all the bright colours flashing on screen.
All in all, its a decent pick if you get it on sale. Its definitely worth the hour or two you spend on it.

This platformer is cute with great music.  For me personally it didn't hold my interest.  However if you are a platform junkie and like games with cool music you could do worse. Which is a shame, because I really wanted to like it.\n\nThe game is also too short and minimalistic for me to condone the price. As you progress through 140, admiring the beautifully simplistic aesthetic design and navigating through its gauntlet of platforming puzzles, you learn that its substantial soundtrack is inextricably linked to these obstacles, and builds itself as you progress through each level. This progression and unification of elements is consistently satisfying and results in a truly gestalt video game experience. It’s a short game, but carries no fluff or fat and accomplishes exactly what it sets out to. Each level is crafted with care and an eye toward creative challenge, and the later boss battles especially will push the limits of your hand-eye comprehension. It may sound elementary, but if you love music, color, and good platformers, you should not pass this up.

140 is a great minimalist, hardcore platforming game with a unique twist: the level changes to the beat of the music. Platforms will appear, grow, shrink, move, blink out of existence, or become deadly to touch at the beat. Walls and hazards will rhythmically turn on and off. It's really very cool. You are an entrepid little monochromatic shape braving the dangers of the three levels and overcoming the bosses at the end of each. If you manage to beat them all, you will be granted an even more challenging adventure (and seriously, the last boss is a huge jerk. Like, really really mean.) I just beat the entire game (and unlocked all achievements, which was nice), and it took me about 6 hours, which is impressive considering if done perfectly, you could probably do the whole game in less than 15 minutes. I think it was worth the money spent.

I love the simplicity of the game's graphics, controls, and objectives, I love the precision and timing involved, and I love the music for this game! The only thing I can think of that I don't like about this game is what happens when you die... I die a lot, and every time it happens I jump out of my chair... If you like heart attacks, seriously pick up this game.

As a final note, this game is on sale ALL THE TIME. you can either wait and grab it for $1-$3, or support the dev and maybe help them get more games out by paying full price, which I recommend.

2 hours of exhilarating & pulsating fun is how this rhythm game can and should be described. People have different tastes, of course, but for lovers of puzzles and those who don't mind a bit--only a bit because this game isn't THAT difficult--of mental workout, 140 is a winner. Screens are simple, colorful--you might even wanna snap a couple of them and use them as wallpapers on your HD LCDs (I did)--and reverberate with pulsating beat music. Game's beat music is the key to way forward, because you will need to time your moves in rhythm with these beats. Puzzles are intelligently crafted and made me laugh in amazement when  I figured them out. There are, in total, three levels, and at the end of each level, you are challenged with a boss screen. The third level, however, has two boss screens, the last one of which is a disappointment since it is solvable with a fixed sequence of key presses however many times you play it. I like this game in particular above many other puzzlers as it doesn't test you on how fast you are at your keyboard, but instead challenges your patience and alertness by offering you unlimited time for each puzzle piece. 9/10.

A simple platformer that tests your timing and reflexes.  The normal levels are quite fun but the hardcore levels can be a bit frustrating.  Grab this game when it is cheap for a quick little challenge.
